subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: ... This comparison is in senior QS, right? I have a hard time reading it. I too would like to see concrete examples at this point. I have tried to see what QS
messageBody:
Anthony Grahn wrote:
>
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
> <mailto:Read_Alphabet%40yahoogroups.com>, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
> >(There are also splits, where a lexical set divides into two
> >different pronunciations, but QS just can't handle those at all.)
>
> True, QS with the wrong implementation cannot. But QS treated
> phonemically can: I do not believe there has ever been a QS user who
> tried to find a letter for a sound and failed. The problem has been
> the reverse: we find too many letters that work. There are two
> proposals now to solve this:
> 1. do not use letters for sounds not found in your accent.
> 2. follow a complex set of rules to simulate Upper Class British
> English.
> My bias is towards number 1.
>
> >> it is just one letter out of 6 in one word out of 50 and is
> unimportant.
> >Au contraire. Hundreds of thousands of words are affected.
>
> I'm sure you have a basis for this figure even though it so very
> strongly resembles a complete guess. It would perhaps be better to
> show us an Australian and Non-Australian version of the same text side
> by side as I have done with US vs RP here:

> http://quickscript.tonygrahn.com/spellcomparison.html

This comparison is in senior QS, right? I have a hard time reading it. I
too would like to see concrete examples at this point. I have tried to
see what QS might look like if written phonetically for the Australian
dialect. (My understanding is that there are not letters for some of the
sounds in Australian English; but at least show this in a concrete
example and try to approxtimate). But I can't find a really good list of
words.

The words wouldn't have to be in QS; they could appear side by side with
their IPA transcriptions for each word.

This is all I've been able to find so far:

Australian "day" sounds like "die";
Australian "buy" sounds like "boy".
